column1: [  About This School\rDistrict Contact Information (School Year 2018-2019)\rDistrict NameElk Grove Unified\rPhone Number(916) 686-5085\rWeb Sitewww.egusd.net\rSuperintendentChristopher R. Hoffman\rE-mail Addresschoffman@egusd.net\rSchool Contact Information (School Year 2018-2019)\rSchool NameRobert J. McGarvey Elementary\rStreet4350 Sophistry Dr\rCity
column4: CA 95742\rPhone Number(916) 793-3400\rPrincipalMichael Gulden\rE-mail AddressMGulden@egusd.net@egusd.net\rWeb Sitehttp://blogs.egusd.net/mcgarvey/\rCounty-District-School(CDS) Code34673140135392\rSchool Description and Mission Statement (School Year 2018-2019)\rThe vision of RJMES is to provide a rigorous
column5: high-quality education that challenges every individual to excel in his/her\rstudies
column6: encourages both personal and academic achievement
column7: and fosters intercultural understanding and respect. It is no\rcoincidence that these ideals define the man for whom our school is named
column8: Mr. Robert J. McGarvey. Our faculty is\rcommitted to these ideals and to collaboration with families and the broader community to ensure this is accomplished.\rDeveloping students' leadership potential
column10: and creating opportunities for students to\rflourish in an environment of shared values and good character are hallmarks of our learning community. Our Positive\rBehavior Intervention and Support (PBIS) team will work diligently to equip our faculty to help in building a school where\reveryone is valued and respected
column11: and where rules and character are explicitly taught and expected. The profile of all\rlearners in the RJMES journey - children and adults alike - is captured in the acronym S.O.A.R. which highlights the essential\rattributes of our Safe
column14: and Resilient community.\rPartnerships with families and community agencies to provide opportunities for challenge and growth are central to our\rcommitment to serving the whole child. We will work tirelessly to provide a well-rounded experience for our children so that\rthey are ready for wherever their futures take them. Leadership experiences
column21: and academic enrichment are all as important to the growth of the whole child as core academic\rprogram.\rThe concept of community
column23: is a priority for our parents
column25: and students. It is clear that our\rcommunity understands that a strong relationship between the home and school is a recipe for student success. I encourage\ryou to become part of our Parent Faculty Organization
column26: an amazing group dedicated to making McGarvey a world class\rinstitution. It's in this spirit that I encourage you to become involved to support our school. Together
column27: Griffins SOAR to\rincredible heights!\rHere's to another Griffincredible Year!\rMike Gulden

Overall Facility (School Year 2018-2019)\rYear and month of the most recent FIT report: NA\rOverall Rating\rExemplaryGoodFairPoor\rThe custodial team provides supervision and maintenance from 6:30 am - 11:00 pm. During these hours the school facilities\rare thoroughly cleaned
column4: playground maintained and restrooms checked hourly. District maintenance\rstaff ensures repairs necessary to keep the school in working order are completed in a timely manner. A work order process\ris used to ensure efficient service and that emergency repairs are given the highest priority. The district governing board has\radopted cleaning standards for all schools. A summary of these standards is available at the district Facilities Department.\rThe principal works with the custodial staff to develop cleaning schedules to ensure a clean and safe school. The State\rDeferred Maintenance Program (DMP) was established in 1980 to aid districts in major maintenance projects. Beginning with\rthe 2013-2014 fiscal year and the inception of the Local Control Funding Formula (LCFF) the State has intended for Deferred\rMaintenance needs and expenses to be included in the District's LCFF allotment. The district funds routine restricted\rmaintenance beyond the State required minimum and uses local resources to fund projects previously considered part of the\rstate DMP. The district's complete deferred maintenance plan is available at the district office. There are no corrective actions\rnecessary at this time.\rThe State Deferred Maintenance Program (DMP) was established in 1980 to aid districts in major maintenance projects.\rBeginning with the 2013-2014 fiscal year and the inception of the Local Control Funding Formula (LCFF) the State has\rintended for Deferred Maintenance needs and expenses to be included in the District's LCFF allotment. The district continues\rto fund routine projects previously considered as part of the State's former DMP at levels required by the State and continues\rto use local resources.\rNone at this time.  ... Unnamed: 2
